citations.narrative:
Several primary enclosures need maintenance and/or repair:
• A primary enclosure housing an African crested porcupine, had a wooden framed doorway within the enclosure. The
doorway was surrounded by a heavy gauge metal fence panel with the metal panel inside the opening of the doorway cut
away. Sticking up across the bottom of the doorway were 10 sharp metal spiked remnants of the panel, approximately 1.5
inches in height.
• A primary enclosure housing several goats had an elevated wooden platform with a wooden ramp. The ramp was
approximately 4 feet wide and 6 feet long with seven 1”X1” boards spaced out horizontally across the ramp. One
horizontal board was hanging down and not attached on one side with two other boards totally off and laying on the
ground at the foot of the ramp. Both of these boards had numerous screws sticking up approximately 3 inches.
• A primary enclosure housing water buffalos had a metal tube framed wire fence gate. The gate had one vertical and one
horizontal pipe in the center of the gate. Where the pipes met at the center of the gate, the pipes were rusted and no
longer welded together. This caused the gate to sit at an odd angle leaving a gap approximately 12 inches wide where the
gate met the bottom of the connecting fence.
Primary enclosures that are not kept in good repair may no longer effectively contain the animals or might create hazards
which can injure the animals housed within them.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain
the animals. To be corrected by May 22, 2025

Several primary enclosures need maintenance and/or repair:
• A primary enclosure housing a white cockatoo has a metal food and water dish holder. The top inside edge of the holder
is rusted and broken along the top of the three dish holders. This broken metal strip was angled inward towards the bird
as it uses the bowls and had pitted rust with sharp jagged edges.
• A primary enclosure housing chickens has a wooden floor made of plywood. Sections of the plywood are broken off and
missing, leaving small holes and sharp, jagged edges.
Primary enclosures that are not kept in good repair may create hazards which can injure the birds housed within them.
Primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp
points or edges that could injure the birds. To be corrected by May 22, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Shawna Abrams, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several primary enclosures need maintenance and/or repair: 
• A primary enclosure housing an African crested porcupine, had a wooden framed doorway within the enclosure. The 
doorway was surrounded by a heavy gauge metal fence panel with the metal panel inside the opening of the doorway cut 
away. Sticking up across the bottom of the doorway were 10 sharp metal spiked remnants of the panel, approximately 1.5 
inches in height. 
• A primary enclosure housing several goats had an elevated wooden platform with a wooden ramp. The ramp was 
approximately 4 feet wide and 6 feet long with seven 1”X1” boards spaced out horizontally across the ramp. One 
horizontal board was hanging down and not attached on one side with two other boards totally off and laying on the 
ground at the foot of the ramp. Both of these boards had numerous screws sticking up approximately 3 inches. 
• A primary enclosure housing water buffalos had a metal tube framed wire fence gate. The gate had one vertical and one 
horizontal pipe in the center of the gate. Where the pipes met at the center of the gate, the pipes were rusted and no 
longer welded together. This caused the gate to sit at an odd angle leaving a gap approximately 12 inches wide where the 
gate met the bottom of the connecting fence. 
 
Primary enclosures that are not kept in good repair may no longer effectively contain the animals or might create hazards 
which can injure the animals housed within them. 
 
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain 
the animals. To be corrected by May 22, 2025 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Several primary enclosures need maintenance and/or repair: 
• A primary enclosure housing a white cockatoo has a metal food and water dish holder. The top inside edge of the holder 
is rusted and broken along the top of the three dish holders. This broken metal strip was angled inward towards the bird 
as it uses the bowls and had pitted rust with sharp jagged edges. 
• A primary enclosure housing chickens has a wooden floor made of plywood. Sections of the plywood are broken off and 
missing, leaving small holes and sharp, jagged edges.

Primary enclosures that are not kept in good repair may create hazards which can injure the birds housed within them. 
 
Primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp 
points or edges that could injure the birds. To be corrected by May 22, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Shawna Abrams, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
